description.text: This was designed specifically for the Printrbot Simple 2014, but should work with any Printrbot (or any 3D printer for that matter) that has plywood 6.25mm thick.

Quick Printing Tip
Each of the objects will need to be rotated 90° on the Y axis and centered to print correctly. (I also rotate 90° on the X axis because the prints seem to come out a little better when the build platform is doing most of the moving instead of the Y axis.) You will need to print whichever file you choose 4 times for a complete set of Feet Stabilizers. Now back to the show... Inspiration
I was looking around and saw there were no foot stabilizers to my liking, so I used AutoDesk 123D Design to design the part. I was inspired by the shape of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:95459 and how it fits around the wood. So I took a few measurements and drew it up in 123D Design. The first version (V1) was the most basic just based on measurements. V2 removes a good portion of "dead space" to save on time and filament and also creates a bit of springiness to dampen vibration and helps keep the printer from rocking (like a bar stool with 1 short leg) V3 has not been printed / tested yet, but the thought behind its design was to further stabilize the "wobbly bar stool" scenario. I also believe it will help with X axis stabilization of the whole printer as each of the V2 feet act like a set of (2) V3 feet. Suggestions?
Please feel free to edit the file or let me know if there is a way to improve the design.

May/June 2014 marks the 35th Anniversary of one of the most brilliant Sci-Fi classics, Alien (and one of the few movies that truly scared the crap out of me as a kid.) Print with supports for the head, the mouth can be tricky to clean out I can post a cut up version of the head if people wish. The back tubing was cut from the body in case anyone doesn't want to use it, it takes very little extra to print them but since they are not joined, its up to you if you use them or not. note Slicing the alien bust takes a few minutes (or it did on an 8-core cpu..) so I would go make a coffee while that's happening. I am printing this currently, it's a 3-4 hour print depending on your machine and settings, I'm going for 0% infill and 2 shells on the alien and 3%infill and 1 shell for the base. I can supply a low res version of this mesh if necessary, but you will lose alot of detail, this is why I chose to keep it a high count. The jaw has been seperated and printable standing upright, you may or may not want to use it.. (it does look pretty evil with the second jaw tho.. ) Thanks to Frank Munz, an awesome modeller. He created a low poly mesh I used for the bust and used that to sculpt upon like I do with so many other busts. It's sort of like getting a real life foam base head, throwing a bunch of clay over it and then resculpting it. I did the base in Blender also... There is another base I didn't quite finish which is more Giger style, with embedded mechtronics, but its still got some ways to go. My advice, print the alien and the jaws, the new base should be ready in a day or so.

Created to hold electronic devices for shipment and storage, designed in Solidworks. Complete with hinged lid and latches. Although made for holding specific devices, without the tray this box functions as a multi purpose container.

comments.text:
It needs to be rotated and printed with the bottom flat on the print surface, not on its side like it is when you import the file into MakerBot. The cut-outs were created so that inserts with logos printed upright and separately could be put in that location. I will go ahead and upload a model file with solid bottom and top, but will keep the triangular grooves. They really do aid in removing such a large object from the print surface, and remain characteristic of the design.
I just used the standard settings for ABS: 0.2 layer height, no raft or supports (model has supports designed into it), extrusion temp 230C, print platform 110C on Kapton tape.
Thanks for the interest in my model :)

description.text:
Azim 3MM Direct Drive Extruder version 2 with some tweaking and further improvement, now added spring tension knob to adjust the pressure on the filament.   
Also minimized free travel area for the filament for better grip between the idler and the drive gear. Any drive gear with OD 10.88 mm to 11.00 mm will work great.  
I have made it for Mendelmax 1.5 with X-carriage lugs pillow and E3D Hotend, will post some pictures soon.  
For now this is working great, should you make one do upload pictures and let me know your comments.  
Print it and enjoy!!!

Print it without supports infill 70 ~ 80% will give good results and layer thickness 0.2mm. You would need spring with OD 6.00mm and length 12~15mm.
Also 608ZZ bearing for idlear. 10.88~11.00 mm drive gear and NEMA 17 motor. Any comments or suggestions are welcome. Enjoy 3D printing!!!

description.text:
This CNC-foam cutter is the product of a project done by group 5 during the 41030 Mechatronics Design at the Technical University of Denmark. The foaminator is produced both in the workshop and on a laser cutter. It operates on the H-bot principle using G-code and is run by two steppermotors.
The code for homing can be found on this link:
https://github.com/thomas-sonderby/grbl/commit/35d4c664c9e9c362151fed1b296dfc0de0387252 Attached are either files to be lasercut and files to be produced in the workshop. The specifications of the components can be found on the Bill of Materials file

CONSTRUCTION OF THE PARTS: The acrylic sides of the sledges, cross beam and the corner stabilizers are produced on a lasercutter. Files are found above. The rest is made in the workshop and technical drawings can be derived from the CAD-files. The base is made of 10 mm plywood and measures 515x515x120 mm, which are outer dimensions. COMPUTER:
A PSU applies 12 volts to two stepper motors, 5 volts to a nichrome hotwire and 5 volts to two diodes placed in the middle sledge.

Hi,
I'm not quite sure if you mean support or raft. If your print comes off from the bed during printing, then you should enable a raft, or use other techniques that improve stickiness.
Support would be needed if there are overhanging parts that overhang with a certain angle. This part I designed so that the overhanging connector has a rather steep angle, where most printers manage without support. But if you get better results with support, enable it. But I would try without support first.
Joachim

description.text:
This is a device for participating in multiple choice quizzes amongst other people with similar devices. WHAT DOES IT DO:
This quiz box holds a OLED-screen and a joystick as the userinterface. It is controlled by an Arduino, which with the NRF2401L+ component communicates through a link of notes to the final recipient. To look and choose between the different answers you can scrool with the joystick. WHY WE DESIGNED IT:
It's designed to participate in a quiz during the course Mechatronics Design 41030 of the Technical University of Denmark by group 5.
The box was designed to keep the components assembled and protect them. The aim of the bridge in the middle of the box was to keep it as compact as possible and holds the joystick. HOW TO ASSEMBLE IT:
The PDF-files need to be laser cutted. The box is designed for press-fit, but due to kerf acetone may be used for extra security. How to the components are placed can be seen on the CREO-files. HOW TO OPERATE IT:
To operate it you need to download the core24_1 Ardunino file. Upload the code to your Arduino board and connect a 9 volt battery to it.

description.text:
Did you already have fun with the duplo marble run (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:159219)?
Then you are ready for much more fun and challenge!
Extend your marble run with a marble pump inspired by the great work of Matthias Wandel (http://woodgears.ca/marbles/lifter.html).
Push up marbles using the lever. (No motor.) The drop-block mechanism prevents the marbles from falling back.
Please read the instructions.
OpenSCAD files are included.
See marble pump in action:
http://youtu.be/2z1Rwl-ASx4
http://youtu.be/mFvod_YRR_w

You'll need ...
  • Many Marbles (I used 12.7 mm steel marbles). Since in action the pipe above is filled with marbles, you'll need enough to fill the pipe.
  • Two simple elastic rubber bands.
  • A M3 screw (ca. 15 mm long). (Optionally an M3 nut, but typically not needed.)
  • A small file to make the drop-block slide in easily.
    After printing the base, lid, lever and drop-block put it all together.
    The longer drop-block is for smaller marbles. (12.7 mm, 1/2 ")
    The shorter drop-block is for larger marbles. (up to 15 mm)
    Check if the drop-block slides in the slot easily. Otherwise use the file to open the slot a bit.
    Attach a rubber band that pulls the drop-block back when pushed out.
    Use a 3 mm screw as lever axis. (On one side the hole is smaller, which typically makes a nut unnecessary.)
    Attach a rubber band through the loop on the base that pulls the lever back, after pushing it down. (See foto. Before attaching the lever put the rubber band twice through the loop and attach it on the two nobs.)
    Test the marble pump before putting on the lid.
    If everything works fine, print as many pipe pieces as you like.
    Also recommended is the top pipe piece to send your marbles in a certain direction. And the tapering ramp piece which helps to prevent marbles getting stuck when entering the side hole.
    If your marbles are too small and slip back, then print a longer drop block.
    Have fun.

comments.text: The duplo run parts this is compatible with this uses large openings and wide runs, it works well with the 16-17 mm glass marbles we have all over the house but they are too big for this pump sadly. Apparently 16mm give or take .5 for variance is one of the most common sizes and larger than the 15mm  this pump is designed for.

Side table.
My first attempt to create something "really big"
Made of 4 parts, connected with M8 bolts.

Some comments; You'll have to print both parts 2x, the thing is not symetrical!
The holes for the bolts are a bit short, I would advice adding 5mm.
Holes are for M8 bolts I had some underextrusion on my Ultimaker2 at some of the prints, the last part came out perfect at: layer: 0,2
Shell: 1,2
Fill: 30%
Speed 30 mm/s This was a 25 hour print (!) but any higher speed resulted in underextrusion on my machine. the source file is a "design spark mechanical" file, my favourite free 3D software....

Selection panel for button

This is a simple iPhone 5/5s handlebar mount for your bike.
It is pretty tight but in return it does not fall of while riding.
You are still able to plug in the dock-connector, audio-jack and use the speakers and side buttons.
There is a version for 25.4mm and 31.8mm handlebars make sure you get the right one.
See also the instructions.

Instructions
print with support and raft (i know, a lot of wasted material but no screws ;) )
This settings worked for me:
PLA
infill: 25%
Numbers of shells: 3
layer height: 0.25mm
about 3 hours
Mounting:
  • i used two 5mm cable ties
  • (place a piece of bike tube or grip tape or something similar to prevent the mount from rotating around the handlebar)
  • pull the cable ties tight

description.text: Receiver old version

Some days planning to conquer the universe takes a lot out of you. On those days I just wish I had an army of genetically altered peoples from Skaro, entirely devoid emotions except for ambition and hatred, enclosed in a metallic casing providing them with all the weaponry, communications, necessities for survival and universal domination. If you're like me, this cookie cutter may be just what you're looking for. Each STL contains plans for two cookie cutters. If people want a single-Dalek cookie cutter, let me know and I'll upload an STL for that. More on this design at http://makerblock.com/2010/07/new-design-dalek-cookie-cutter/ or more MakerBot/RepRap/3D printing and design frivolity at MakerBlock.com

• Print one STL to get two Daleks.
  • Order each Dalek to create a MakerBot.
  • Order each Dalek to use their MakerBot to print one STL to get two Daleks.
  • LRR ( http://makerblock.com/2010/06/skeinforge-ui-suggestions/#footnote_0_1590 )

description.text:
Moira Brown will give it to you and asks you to insert it in the mainframe of the RobCo Facility.  
The insert piece does press fit into it, so you need to make sure your printer has good calibration.  
All I had to go by was the black and white drawing from the Wiki. I think i did pretty well.  
For somereason the photos don't show the right way up.

Both parts are fine details. The Widget I think I did .2mm layer, 25% infil and 0 shells.  
The Widget inside since since it is only 1mm thick. I did .2mm Layer, 100% fill, and 0 shells. (It took 15 minutes to print the inside)  
Once done, do a small amount of clean up around the single hole on the bottom of the inside, then just press it into the main body.

description.text: I saw this on you tube and wanted one, but found that the price was too steep for me. So I made one instead. This is a adjustable width PCB Holder with component holder so that you can flip it and solder. Can adjust the PCB to any 12 orientation on one axes and thus work easily on it. Very handy. This project is using the Library from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6021

• Print all the parts. You will need a few copies of each part in these quantities
    a. Handle x2
    b. Handlemiddle x2
    c. Shims x2
    d. ShimNotched x2
    e. PCBHolder x2
    f. pcbframeOneSpar x12

  • Bolt all together. You will need a bag full of M3 Nuts and 23mm bolts.
    you will also need some M5 Nuts and Thumb bots, and 4 M6 Nuts.
    Then 2 M6 Bolts at least 100mm long.
    Two 22mm pipes and finally 2 Springs.

  • The spring goes inside the handle between the middle part and handle.

  • Get some Mechano or equivalent to make the hold arms so that way you can place the arm over the component and flip it over to work on it without it falling out.

  • Enjoy

A open-clasp design cheeseborough clamp for hanging lightfixtures and other items onto 1-1/4"-1-1/2" NPT pipe. Use at your own risk.

Assembly:
  • Use a 1/4"-20 barrel nut and 2-1/2" to 3"x1/4"bolt for the closing lock, print a knob (not included yet) and assemble.
  • Print top and bottom halves, assemble using a 2"x3/8" bolt with nylock nut for the hinge.
  • Press fit 1/4" bolt, or nut depending on your preferences into the bottom half for mounting fixtures, etc.
    • Notes:
  • At 40% infill with ABS this seems to support 20-30lb of tension minimum (the most I could exert by pulling on it with a luggage scale in-line). Further testing to be performed
  • Recommend use of a washer in between the knob and the top clamp.

comments.text: First I did it in illustrator and exported it as a vector image. When I imported it to the cad software it was lots of problems to make an extrude of the spline curve so I gave up. Went back to Illustrator, saved it as a pixel image, did a image trace, and exported it as a vector image again. You miss some resolution that way but on the other hand you get good curves:-) After that I imported it to a cad software and made an extrude of the sketch. The hole and the threads in the nut, was done in the cad software. I guess it would have been better to do it in a cad software from scratch:)

author: blueq01

description.text:
You know the drill - where are the tweezers, the X-acto knife or that piece of rod you need to get the plastruder's pinch roller set right? Add the hunt for the Sharpie pen marker to write the temperature, extrude rate and some other vital statistics onto the latest calibration object's raft. This 3D Printer Accessory Holder saves the day (well, sort of). The 7-sided septagon shape is pretty unique and would be real hard to build without, what else, a 3D printer. The accessory holder is a derivative of the "Talisman Holder, i.e. Septagon Box and Lid":
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1437
The designer of that object did 99% of the work on this derivative. All I did was increase the size of the box height by about double, and increase the size of the whole lid to form a stand for the new box to fit into. The overall object size was increased by 10%, which seems about right. The photo shows the original box and lid to the left of my MakerBot accessory holder version. Oh yeah, it also works fine as a pencil holder....

The files below print a stand which is about 63mm across.  Printed fine on my MakerBot without a heated platform, but your results may vary.  The new base box size is about 70mm high with the stand on it. 
Like the original box, the stand is a separate STL file from the base so you can print this holder in 2 different colors if you want.  I forgot to click on the 'Outside Extruded First' in the SkeinForge FILL menu, so the base came out looking sort of like rough hewn wood.  Be sure you have that feature checked or plan on a lot more sanding to get smooth sides.  I sort of liked the effect and left it rough.
The stand fits tight into the new base box, but you decide if some ABS glue is needed or not - I did not use any on mine.  Printing varies so you may need to sand the base to get the stand to fit right.

author: AdelK

description.text: I recently had a crash that snapped my landing gear right by a screw. I was able to plastic weld it, but I wanted new gear. These are about the same size and angle as the original landing gear, except I went big where the skids go through so they would stick to the bed easier. I used green because that is what was on my printer at the time and I didn't expect the prototype to work the first time out. I have gotten pretty good at flying and put very little stress on my landing gear, so these should last me a while if I can keep from crashing. These are pretty sturdy and should be able to take a decent hit like the original gear. The rear end if the skids are really jammed in the gear and I couldn't get them out. That is why they do not go all the way through. I left them as is because they were sturdy enough. I made the tail fin too. That is available at http://www.thingiverse.com/make:78454. My PLA is MakerGeeks Ultra PLA at http://makergeeks.com/ulplafi.html.

Since the gear itself it pretty square and exactly 9mm high, you can print at .3 layers.  
You might have to scale the skids up or down a little to get them just right. I scaled them up to 103% and they are really jammed in there. If they are a little loose, use CA to really secure them well. Also, I used a 2mm brim to keep it stuck to the bed. Without the brim it curled.

This Mars base consist of a large pyramid that is hidden beneath the terrain in order to escape the harsh environment that exist above ground. The pyramid is topped by a geodesic dome that serves as an observation deck, greenhouse, and power supply. The dome panels would be constructed of a material that can convert solar radiation into usable energy while keeping the damaging rays out of the dome. A large vertical turbine sits atop the dome and uses the winds to create more energy. Inside the pyramid are three levels which serve as housing, storage, and work areas. Large cylinders surround the pyramid storing water and fuel.

An experiment intended to reduce Z wobble in prusa i2 printers.
The holes are deliberately sized to fit perfectly straight off the bed. The holes in the wings should allow an M3 screw to slide through without much resistance but also without much play, the holes in the centerpiece should be super tight so you can actually cut a thread by driving the M3 screw in.
The motor shaft has a single nut trap for the flat, the threaded rod has 3 nut traps in case some alignment is needed.
8x M3x10 or M3x15 screws and 4x M3 nuts are required for each Universal Joint.

1) print
2) assemble using M3 screws
3) install
4) post before/after picture as an "I made one" :)

description.text: just a test
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

People have seen the front of their HBP sag almost 2mm after 30 minutes. Before this modification I was getting 1.8mm sag after 30 minutes and now .45mm sag after 30 minutes.   
If you don't have access to a laser cutter let me know and we can work something out.

It's a simple fix. It's just some additional support without adding a lot of weight.   
You will need 6 M3 16mm bolts & nuts. Disassemble and replace the main plate. I've included the two back plates and the front plate because I found the orginial files were not the same as the shipping model of the Replicator so I updated them to match and I modified the back to be more Replicator2 styled. Just cut it all out on a laser cutter with 5mm plywood.  
I also added a center hole up front so if you want to modify your HBP to 3 point its ready to go.  
If you want one of these in a kit form let me know I can do it for $25 which includes shipping if you're in the USA.

comments.text:
I am about to make this on our laser cutter, and will hopefully help our problems with the build plate, along with aluminum plates on the sides of the arms.
One question: It seems like the holes in the horizontal plate for mounting the (vertical) back plate is 6mm, but the instructions say that it should be cut from 5mm - why is that? Are the back plates (and the angled one in front with the MB logo) in fact cut from 6mm, and the rest from 5mm?
Thanks.

comments.text: To get this cut yes it's a reasonable price but you don't need the additional support with bottle works arms. If you just want to get rid of the wood you would be best to stick with the original design without my support ribs. Those support arms are just because it uses wood that gets weak when hot and bends. An aluminum bottom wouldn't need it and the aluminum arms hold the wood so well it wouldn't flex if you tried. In other words bottle works arms negate the need for this but at a higher cost.

Just curious if a "heat shield" (kapton with foam or so) between HPB and plastic/woodÂ carrierÂ platform, also would contribute in lessÂ deformingÂ warping / sagging of the HPB. Together with the nice upgrade you made of course.

description.text: Mini bowling table for marble or large marble

Okay mini bowling game need either marble or large marble or something similar.  The bowling pins have holes for tread to be attached, tread goes through appropriate holes on board to front of the board. Thread should very thin and strong, should be loose as well, so you can bowl pins yet reset them when needed. Thread needs to be attached to a toothpick when you have finished threading through holes.  Do not have a 3d printer yet, this was just a thought. Pins may need some weight added to help keep them upright, also scale of board may be off, no marbles in house.

comments.text: Consider this a work in progress, building a 3d printer. In the Future will add a spring driven alignment spikes through holes for pins with a lever arm to bring down spikes once pins are in place. This way no thread but pins will be placed on spikes by hand. That will take a while though unless someone else does it first.

remixed_from.title: Active Cooling Fan Duct for Replicator 1 / Duplicator 4 / FlashForge

title: Simplified bracket for Active Cooling Fan Duct - CTC / FlashForge

description.text:
This is a bracket to attach my Active Cooling Fan Duct to a CTC or FlashForge printer without the need of the rarely available M3x60 bolts. A second benefit is that you can click in and out the front cooling duct without any tool and without loosing your active cooling height setup. If you use a plug-able 2 pin connection for the front fan you can even dead easy remove it fully. All credits for this design go to JakobWelner who had this brilliant idea!
His design works with my WanHao Duplicator 4 but because of the wider extruder aluminum mount block of the CTC and FlashForge printers the dual extruder fan distance is higher and as a result JakobWelners clip doesn't fit here. So mine is basically a redraw to make it fit on my CTC printers. Because FlashForge printers use the same extruder mount block I'm sure it works on FlashForge Creators, too. You will need the following parts to mount my Active Cooling Fan Duct with this clip:
2x M3 nuts
2x M3x14 hex screws (or alternatively M3x16 typically shipped as spare parts with the printers) Because the front cooling duct can be easily clicked into the carriage we don't need to finally tighten the extruder fan screws at the end and can print a version of my Active Cooling Fan Duct without the inner holes inside of the air way. This adapted version of the duct ActiveDuctD4_V1_nohole.STL you can download in my thing.

I printed it with 0.1 layer height, 2 shells and 100% infill. I didn't care that the 1mm plate underneath the fans has a small gap between the shells. Anyways it works flawless!  
Print orientation should stay like in the STL files so that the future front is aligned to the build plate while printing.

comments.text: Please read instructions of the actual active cooling duct this braket is designed for. Or the improved version v2 which does not need this bracket. There you will find the answer to your question.

comments.text: This is a very clever way to mount the active cooling! Thanks to you, and the other parent Things, for pulling this together. Very, very cool!
comments.author: laird

comments.text:
It's great to see another version of my bracket for other types of printers!
Word of warning to Flashforge/Makerbot users: This design is missing the Arm that touches the Y-Axis stop sensor!
Without that missing part, you will Damage your printer! It will make an awful sound, grinding and trying to move the print head to the right further and further and never hit the stop sensor because this bracket is missing the arm. The bracket, any bracket, adds width to the print head which make it not make contact. That is why my original design includes an arm.
comments.author: activezombie

comments.text:
Wow, you name a lot horror scenarios for JakobWelners and my adaption of it.
Did you print and try my or JakobWelners thing or do you just think there could be a problem?
It works on both of my AX1058 printers without any of your predicted problems. And JakobWelners bracket works on my Duplicator 4. All AX1058 (FlashForge Crator & CTC Creator and some others) have the same mechanics and electronics and only differ in their case crew-position and type of wood. Your design (you name 'original') has a wider side arm and that's why you might have had trouble with the X axis end stop and you have needed the arm to avoid the problems you you mentioned above. The Y axis endstop you mentioned is not affected in any way even with your design. Basicly JakobWelner was influenced by your design when he picked up the idea to mount my fan duct without the long screws. The way his duct to extruder adapter is mounted is different and that's why I like it so much cause you can easily snap the front duct in and out if you're cleaning the extruders.
I have read the comments on your bracket. To avoid beeing blamed for problems people have with my duct and not your bracket you should JUST link to my duct and don't store a copy of my stl in your thing file list.
comments.author: activezombie

Image2stl,is a software that allows the creation of 3D object from a 2D base (jpg or png). Associating the colors to values â€‹â€‹extrusion, the program detects differences in color level to translate the 2D to 3D. Thus, an image composed of a gradient from black to white gradient will create a volume.
This application has been designed by the Association Design The Future Now and developed by JoÃ«l Belouet.

Currently, image2stl only takes jpg, jpeg or png with a colored background (white and black included - no transparency) preferably in contrast to the subject of the image. Each color represents a brightness value used differently, and therefore translation image2stl a value different extrusion. Thus, an image composed of a gradient going from white to black will create a volume having the shape of a slope.

While in Thailand me and my friend came across this somewhat addictive bar game and when coming back,
I didn\'t have enough money to get my own (well budgeted trip ;). I thought \"Oh well.. no worries thou, I have a Makerbot. I\'ll make my own and with some improvements.\" So I decited to create a travel version of the game. Not like the big and bulky one they sell over there but small,
sleek and pocket size. Something you can take with you on travels and stuff. And also I wanted to design it so that you wouldn\'t need extra parts to assemble it.
(If you own a makerbot, you can make this in the middle of the desert if needed) (and for a added bonus. I included one extra set of game pieces that read instead of \"Jackpot\" but \"TheGame\") For this you can either use jmil:s dices that has more realistic corners ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:925 ) or mine that has sharp corners.

• Print all the parts. (The lid is optional)
  • Clip off the lid supports.
  • Use soldering iron (or glue) to combine the left and right parts together.
  • Take a little more than box length of filament and put it thru all the game pieces in order (and box sides) and infuse the filament to the box sides.
  • Take 2 pieces of filament (or one long one the length of the box) a little longer than first hinge but long enough so it goes well in to the lid hinge and infuse it to the sides.
    • -DONE- --Instructions for the game-- This game is really fast to play and has really versatile rules (with rules the difficulty can be adjusted).
    Subtract, multiply, divide, etc... Basic rules:
  • The main idea is to flip all the pieces up so that they read \"Jackpot\".
  • You do this by rolling two dices and using either ones number OR their combined number to flip up the game piece.
  • This is repeated until you can\'t flip anymore or the pieces read \"-Jackpot-\"
    • And for a experience I can tell that 1 in 50 usually goes thru (imagine after that if it would read \"TheGame\" ;). Example (\'addition\' rule): You have pieces 1-9 up and you roll 3 and 5.
    Then you can flip 3, 5 or 8. Dual player rules (for example): The other takes all the pieces down and other all up.
    Then at start both choose 4 pieces to either stay up or down. (4 up, 4 down and one joker)
    After the throw player can either choose to put other players piece down or their own up.
    Continue until the throwing player gets all their pieces up/down...
    (Can take few beers to clear the winner :) And when you\'re done playing the lid locks in place and keeps the dices and stuff sealed inside for the next gaming experience.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This Sphero WaterBall Housing Accessory is my submission to the Sphero #Make5000 competition.
It allows the Sphero to move through the water more quickly and easily.
It should be sold with the Sphero Nubby. The Sphero would go inside the Nubby, which would then be placed inside the WaterBall Housing. The Nubby would create friction so that the Sphero wouldn't spin freely inside the housing.
Or, the design could be downsized and made of a rubber-like material so that the Sphero could be placed straight into the housing without the Nubby, and still wouldn't spin freely.
Other features of the design:
  • The housing can roll over almost all surfaces, and it would even provide better traction.
  • If it was made with a rubber-like material, the housing would help prevent damage from jumps and falls by acting as a shock-absorber.
  • Since the housing raises the Sphero off the ground, it would also be protected from things that would scratch or damage it.
    ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

• Download and print the second file
  • Place Sphero in one of the halves, then connect the other half by putting the pegs in the holes and then twisting. It should fit snugly, but if it is too big you should be able to place the Sphero in a Nubby first, and then in the housing, and if it is too small, well, then you are probably going to have to print a slightly larger version.
  • HAVE FUN!

description.text: Printed these to fix the drawer stops on our sink.  The stops that were part of the original broke rather quickly.

These are a temporary solution.  If it works well would be better to get some nylon M3-0.5x6 screws but in the mean time this helps a lot.  The spacers work great though.

This is an expandable mars base idea. It can be built to any length and can be connected via the hatch adapters, and they can be placed between any of the arch segments.  
Due to my limited SketchUp skills I can not model the skins for this, though they would not really be printable.  
The inside of the skeleton would hold an inflatable bladder that would create the livable environment. The idea behind the bladder is that it would be compact because it could be folded. The bladder could be expandable by having rigid rings that could be attached to each other in order to allow the skeleton to be expanded.  
An outer layer would provide the insulation, radiation protection and dust storm protection. Perhaps a strong canvas material could provide ample protection from winds and dust.   
The skeleton would also be held down by straps that are connected to anchors to prevent movement in wind.  
The idea I had in mind was that this could actually be printed on a large printer actually on mars. That way the building material could be densely packed so that the main constraint for shipping would be weight as apposed to space.  
As with other designs power would come from either wind or solar. In the case of solar a CO2 compressor could be employed to create liquefied CO2 for use in a solar panel cleaning system for removing dust after a storm.  
Unfortunately I do not have a complete radiation solution nor an idea of the actual power demands, but then again this is just a concept idea.

Model Information  
I have tried to layout the parts in a way that they should fit, though I can not be sure. Unfortunately I do not have a printer to test with, so if there is anyone that has some plastic to waste, maybe they could try printing a segment and report there results back here. I am quite certain some cleaning will be required and possible some model tweaks.

comments.text:
If you could add crossbars between the ribs to more structurally support the outer shell, you could pile local dirt around the building, providing some protection from wind and blown debris. If it completely covered the building it'd give some protection from radiation, although I'd need to know what the composition of the dirt was to know how much protection per 10cm of 'shielding'. And the ribs would have to be strong enough to support the dirt loading.
I like the modularity provided by the door module. Nice idea!

author: sprue

description.text: TWA Moonliner - built for @Barkleyus internal use. More info: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TWA_Moonliner

This base in designed so that Mars can become a place where a large number of humans can work together to better their knowledge and how we survive of foreign planets. The base is printed on the 3D Printer and then put together in such a way that the central capsule in the center can rotate so that each capsule is isolated. This means precious resources can be saved since that area isn't in use and it means the capsule doesn't need oxygen or other precious aspects that are in use elsewhere. There are 6 separate capsules which all have a different function and there is also the central capsule.  
The first capsule is the scientific capsule which is located at the top of the last photo. The capsule it used to research everything we can about Mars while we are there to discover if what we do is having any effects and for us to have a better understanding of Mars itself and what it's made up of.  
The second capsule is the recreation capsule which is at the top right of the last photo. This is used as a calming place for the astronauts in which it will remind the of home and will have some home comforts to allow them to relax.  
The third capsule is the living capsule which is on the right of the last photo.   This is where all the astronauts can sleep and wash so that they can stay hygienic and be well rested with more comforts from home being here and computers able to send messages back home or to keep a video diary so that the astronauts can have someone to talk to privately improving their mental health dramatically.  
The fourth capsule is the oxygen and water storage which is at the bottom of the last photo. In this capsule all water and oxygen and other elements which make the base habitable are controlled, filtered and disturbed around the base.  
The fifth capsule is the farming capsule which is at the bottom left of the photo. This has two main functions, the first is to grow food for the astronauts to allow staying on Mars a more viable option with food production being able to be closely controlled. The second function it has it to grow dark extremophiles such as lichens and algae and then distribute them all over mars in such a way that Mars' surface absorbs more sunlight increasing the temperature of Mars, which would reduce the albedo of Mars' surface in a sort of terraforming way.  
The sixth capsule is the final capsule and acts as the brain of the base which is at the top left of the last photo. It controls the whole base as would a brain for a human. With all the best conditions being reached in all active areas of the base.  
The central base is all over activities occur and where all astronauts can meet and discuss what is going on.  
The base has many adaptations to it to help it on Mars. With the base of each capsule being drilled into the ground by its platform it is sturdier and less likely to move. The platforms the capsules sit on also act as transport, with all pipes for water, heat and warmth coming from here into each capsule. The windows of the base only point inwards except for the center which has thicker glass so that the dust storms don't become a problem with the windows. Also for the dust storms each capsule has a protective plate which slides across covering the gaps between capsules as shown in second and third photo. To power the base there is solar panels on the center base absorbing as much light as they can to power the base.  The vents at the top of the center base allow the take in and output of gases which allow samples to be taken. Finally the outside of the capsules have thick walls for insulation and at the outer edges of the circle they make and at the bottom have thick radiation shields to protect from what may end up being the true problem on space exploration to Mars.

A c-clamp in any size you want. The provided STL file is for a #8 nut.

1) Procure a hex nut and mating screw of any dimension.
2) Open the c-clamp.scad file.
3) Use the following measurements as arguments to the cclamp module.
3a) nut_od: the nut at its widest part
3b) nut_id: the diameter of the screw
3c) nut_height: the thickness of the nut
3d) spine: the length of the screw
3e) throat: the desired depth of the clamp's throat
4) Compile, render, export to STL.
5) Print.
6) Clean.
7) Put the screw through the hole in the frame and screw on the nut.
8) Align the nut with its hole in the frame.
9) Turn the screw till the nut is pulled firmly into place.
10) Epoxy or glue the screwcap onto the tip of the screw.
11) It's going to be clamp this clamp that. Bada-climp bada-clamp.

description.text:
Version two of the tail pivot system with built in landing gear for a Tricopter. Mounts to a 13mm wood boom.
Made for and Inspired by the Batbone from Flitetest.com.
No longer needs lexan plastic sheet to bolt the motors to. For the front motor mounts see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:351200 Let me know if you have any suggestions or have a specific motor you want this to be modded for. IMPORTANT:
If your motors run too hot the PLA could melt causing a failure, for the first few flights monitor the temperature of the motors. I have about 20+ flights with the extra weight of FPV gear and have had no issues.

PLA, 200 micron 10-35% fill.
Fit for the boom is a little loose to allow for booms that are not exactly 13mm, wood can be wrapped with tape to get a snug fit. Made for "NTM Prop Drive Series 28-26A 1200kv / 250w" motor from hobbyking but can be modded for others, let me know if you have a specific motor you want to fit. Other then electronics you will need:
~10 Zip ties
2mm "music wire" used as a pivot shaft.
1mm "music wire" for servo connection.
Accessory pack for NTM motors. http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__14501__NTM_Prop_Drive_35_Series_Accessory_Pack_EU_warehouse_.html Fits up to 13mm wide, 26mm long servos.
Such as:
BMS-385DMAX Digital Servo (Metal Gear) 4.2kg / .15sec / 16.5g
or
TGY-375DMG Metal gear Digital Servo w/ Heat Sink 2.3kg / .11sec / 11.5g
From hobbyking. Servo is mounted with 2 zip ties
Smaller servos may need a small spacer to give it a snug fit between the landing gear. Tail_servo_rod_mount has break away support, remove before attaching servo rod. (see 3rd photo)

Sized for standard CD's

To create a personal logo-
1) Take the blank CD Case file
2) Create the logo and position it on the front face
3) Copy the logo and scale it up so that it has about 1 mm extra on each side
4) Subtract the larger logo about 1-3 mm into the case
5) Print both the original logo and the case with the logo imprint
6) Glue 'em together.

I've posted topics asking how to come up with the proper print temperature and read many posts as well.  All that came back or what I read was "do it by trial and error", no one really gave any direction.  The more I thought about it, the correct print temperature has to result in the highest bond strength.
So I developed this... The base is 25mm x 5mm, spindle is 10mm x 40mm.

NOTE: This might be obvious to some, but pay attention to the print quality as well as the strength. I just tried my test pieces with some filament from a2aprinter and the best bond was 245C, but the print quality was garbage. So I analysed the pieces (top surface) and picked the strongest piece with the best print quality. This roll has some air bubbles in it as well which would affect the bond strength and the print quality. UPDATE: Green filament is from Repraper (Voxel Factory in Canada). There are 2 rows of 215c, 220c, 225c. The second row is with a FAN cover installed UNDER the headsinks/fans on the Replicator 1. These pieces were the strongest pieces I've ever made!! I could barely break them. However I'm having trouble printing the amazing marble run (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30166) with the FAN cover installed. The bottom of the tracks where the magnet is inserted curls up - the slide portion is fine. I'm going to try reducing my HBP heat from 115C to 105C. To all those that say the FAN cover "might make a difference", I can tell you that the bonding seems about 10x the strength. So much so I was about to get some pilers to break the temp calibration pieces! ** Make sure your platform is level, your filament diameter is correct as all these factors can contribute to bond strength. Print with 10% and 1 extra shell (2 in total). Print at the temperature you think is close to the best. I used 4 settings 230C,235C,240C,245C. Make sure you label them (I labelled base & spindle). As pointed out by theverant in the comments. Speed also affects the bonding of the plastic my test was done at 80mm/s. Higher/Lower will change the print temperature slightly, I'm not sure by how much I haven't experimented with that yet. Once all your desired pieces are printed, grasp the base & spindle and break off the spindle, the result was shocking to me! I was expecting them all to look like 230C (as that's how my objects have been since I got the replicator). The end result 235C was the best bond, it actually ripped off the 3 layers of infill from the base and produced a clearly visible hole! As you can see 245C was going downhill again in bond strength. I believe I'll have to do this for Black, White and coloured plastics. Just wanted to add...
The amount of force required to break the pieces changes as well (which is expected), so even if the end result is similar. Try and gauge the required force as you break the pieces. Unless you own a force gauge :)
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_gauge

I enclosed my printer and put in a light bulb controlled by a simple thermostat; between that and the exhaust fan it maintains the chamber temperature at 90F. This made a big difference in my parts. I have printed parts almost the full bed area on my Emaker Huxley (140 mm square) with only SOME lifting on the corners. The bulk of the part comes out nice and straight.
I've been very frustrated by filament too; some filament foams due to residual styrene monomers and some doesn't. I've gotten stuff from the same company where one batch was beautiful and the next foamed.

Originally designed for an iPad 3, but fits the iPad 4 as it's the exact same dimensions. UPDATE: A new thing has been created for the iPad Air 2 stand: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:989878 UPDATE: I've uploaded "iPad 2 Stand.stl" use this if you have an iPad 2. I wanted a stand that would hold the iPad both in Portrait (with home button accessible) and Landscape. I came across thing 23758 by tealid but it was very square looking and the back support required support material which made it look unfinished. First version I made was just slightly rounded in Tinkercad. But have sinced learned Solidworks which is much more powerful. Pictures/STL attached are of the much improved Solidworks model, but feel free to use the Tinkercad object.

UPDATE: Download "xxx_test.stl" where xxx is the base filename. These are CUT versions using NetFabb Studio for the slot size. As everyone's printer is different, once you determine which slot best fits your iPad. Download the full STL that matches the "_test" version. I've included what I use (9.4mm) as well as .1mm, .2mm, .3mm larger slots. I hope that'll be enough to take into account printer variations. If someone wants an even larger size slot let me know. I have my printer calibrated pretty well, the size of the slot was generated at 9.4mm (8.6mm for iPad 2) which is what Apple lists as the thickness of the iPad. Files attached: iPad Stand.stl -> Slot is 9.4mm, after which additional files: _9.4mm+.1,9.4mm+.2,9.4mm+.3 iPad 2 Stand.stl -> Slot is 8.6mm, after which additional files: _8.6mm+.1,8.6mm+.2,8.6mm+.3 Above files are the base files +.1mm-.3mm larger. The 9.4+.1 and above the slot was moved back .2mm. NOTE: The "ridge" that is seen in the middle of the iPad embossing text on the front has to do with Skeinforge making that entire layer a bridge. I'm not sure of a way to get rid of that. Printed at .27 layer height, 10% Infill, Extra Shells 2 (3 in total) on a Replicator 1 using ABS. Print, wait to cool, remove and insert iPad :) Depending on your retraction settings you may want to smooth out/wet sand the slot where the iPad goes so not to scratch it. Holds the iPad in Portrait (with the home button accessible) or in Landscape. Originally designed using Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/lKTfNYRyg0a-ipad3-the-new-ipad-stand? Later redesigned in Solidworks (you can make much smoother objects because of the Fillet functionality) among other things!

It's definitely is a limitation of the UP! It has a 140x140mm build platform and the STL is right on that limit. with the file un-scaled the UP! complains that the object is too big to print.
That's why - a bit of math told me to get the +.3 and scale it down will make it fit and work.

title: (moved) Stronger  - Yet Another Extruder Filament Drive

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/stronger-yet-another-extruder-filament-drive
Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html Stronger idler arm for "Yet another extruder filament drive"
(Extruder for Thing-o-Matic and earlier Makerbot Industries printers) Changes:
  • thicker front side
  • gave proper names to parametric steps
  • LONG HOLE, so the pressure bolt can come at an angle
  • wider long hole, so an M4 bolt can move freely
  • round hole for bearing (more strength)
  • reshaped sides for added strength
  • wider hole for 608Z bearing
  • wider axis hole for 608Z bearing
    • Stronger body
  • thicker idler arm
  • larger base plate to attach idler arm to
  • wider mounting nut holes
  • gave names to many parametric operations
  • long stepper motor mounting holes to perfectly align
  • ever so slightly smaller mounting blocks
  • allow longer extruder mounting bolts then required
    • Blog postings:
    http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/12/testing-sailfish-firmware-and-new.html
    http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2012/11/improving-gaerisls-extruder.html

Print "_nosupport.stl" directly (already oriented correctly and centered)
or the old way (oriented sideways) with breakaway-support and with "_support.stl". Print the body of the original extruder and assemble.
You can use Jag's quick release or a spring with 2 washers on the long pressure bolt/threaded rod. Tested and works very well on a Thing-o-Martic as an MK6 replacement.
Print with lots of infill! (0.8 works well)
Parts are in INCHES (sorry, it's a derived design and the original was in inches).

More info on streettoolbox.com/wiki/ClipOn
This is a work in progress.
Needed a place to put my shoes so I decided to design this bracket to hang them on the walls.

The stl file is provided for the design.  It is pretty simple and works pretty well with an infill of 10% and at its current scale without supports. 
Just print it out and attach it to the wall with some 3M Command Strips or a similar product (thick double sided tape should work).  This bracket was designed for low top shoes, but it could easily be altered for various applications.  
You can certainly hang other stuff from it as well.

description.text:
Inspired by Thing-O-Fun's "Functional Differential Gear System" I decided i should make one for my RC car. So i did.
I scaled down the gears from the above mentioned Thing, and designed the rest of the parts in my favourite cad software.
And it works surprisingly well, my car is 4WD so i have two of these in the car right now!

The parts may have some adjustments done to fit the settings of my printer so you might have to do some adjustments of your own to make it fit correctly. The "Side Gear Axle" is made of 3mm stainless steel. Other than that check out the exploded view PDF to see how itÂ´s assembled. I made this as an experiment so you should consider it as beeing such a thing. Join the OpenRC discussion at: https://plus.google.com/u/0/communities/112745535856143176146

Maleficent is at last reunited with her wings. Unfortunately, in the higher quality model, her wings are too thin. I used Project miller to make the wings 3D printable, but it also reduced the quality of the rest of the model. I put both the higher and lower quality on here and I will put a middle quality on here soon. If anybody knows how I can make the wings more 3D printable without reducing the quality of the rest of the model, please leave the name of the software and some info in the comments. title: QR Plate for MeFOTO Tripods (Backpacker and RoadTrip)

description.text:
This will work with the MeFOTO RoadTrip or Backpacker tripods. Would I trust this to hold my Hasselblad and telephoto lens securely? Probably not - Use the genuine and beautifully machined MeFOTO part for critical applications (at $28, it is CNC, rock-solid insurance).   
However, this widget is ideal for lighter duty situations, like a point and shoot or (D)SLR.  Perhaps a 3D printed pinhole camera?

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license. with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

Mimicking the MeFOTO plate design at the clamp, the QR plate has been optimized for DIY use - Use a 1/4-20 machine screw, 1/2 inch-long, but spacers will allow you to use longer hardware if necessary. I printed these a 0.20mm layer height, with 2 perimeters, 50% infill, 3 layers top and bottom. Hastily thrown together in Tinkercad (which is still a great quick and dirty CAD app). --------------------------------------------------- In other news, I am reserving judgement on the Thingiverse / Makerbot patent controversy for now.. I try to maintain a certain "brand" in my designs, and openly sharing them through Thingiverse has been central to my personal values and goals for my projects. Further, I am invested in the CC licensing that allows me to share my designs for non-commercial purposes and retain an ownership of them, while allowing derivations and all manner of fair use. Thingiverse and Makerbot have been kind to me, but this situation weighs heavy in my and other Thingiversians' hearts. I hope it can be resolved to everyone's satisfaction.

description.text:
Inspired on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:59075 (Differential Planetary Gearset), but I did it as a modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451(Gear Bearing) script instead.
The concept is EXACTLY the same as Emmett's Planetary Gearset, but I did it using two stacked Gear Bearings instead.
The total gear ratio is printed in the side of the rings (both of them).

Tolerance is a little too tight (0.15) and the attack angle is modified from 45 to 30, making it even worse.
If your machine is not tuned to precision or if you're printing in PLA instead of ABS, consider increasing it.

4x 1/8" screws, 1" long
8x 1/8" screw nuts
4x 1/8" screw washers
1x 3mm screw (if possible, a short and headless one)
1x 3mm nut

1/4" screw and nut (just to "break" the planets free for the first time)
Screwdrivers for 1/8" and 1/4" screws
Pliers

1- Print two matching pieces;
2 - The planets are (probably) stuck, and need a lot of torque to move.
2.1- I break the "lower" gear bearing using the motor coupler, using pliers.
2.2- I bolt a 1/4" screw and nut in the hole of the sun gear of the "upper" gear bearing, that way I can get grip. Once tightened, force it one way to break the planets free.
3 - Break the bridges in the nut traps of the planets to open the hole to the screws.
4- In all planets of the "lower" bearing, put a nut in the nut trap, and a screw the other side, and thighen then a little.
5- Allign all the nuts in the lower planets with the nut traps in the upper ones.
6- Fasten all the planets with a nut and a washer each. It may be a good idea to run it on a drill to soften it, but BE SURE all the parts are tightened, and also check if there is ABSOLUTELLY no axial play on both bearings. 3000 RPM flying parts may result in a nasty accident, do it on your risk. One of my gearsets were all wobble, so I discarded it instead.

comments.text: What slicer was used? I'm using slic3r and having a lot of trouble.  It won't seem to slice correctly.  I even tried importing into netfab and doing a repair.  Still it will not slice.  Any suggestions would be appreciated.
comments.author: NotInTheMafia

comments.text:
I remember having a lot of trouble with slic3r 0.9x finding lots of "non manifold holes".
Slic3r 1.0 until 1.1.1 caused SEVERE vibration in my extruder kit, to the point it was unusable, so I kept using 0.9x for a long while and I had to deal with this problem.
I used Blender, in Edit mode, with "remove doubles" and the CTRL+SHIFT+ALT+M to find those holes and fixing manually... yeah... that was annoying.
Now, with slic3r 1.1.7, I tried again and it worked fine here, even though slicing took a loooooong time.
If you're using slic3r 0.9x because 1.1.x is too slow, consider installing the new version in a different folder, because it is better, but sometimes, too slow.
By the way, I'm using a 0.5mm nozzle (and all widths 0.5 too) and 0.25mm layer height.
comments.author: NotInTheMafia

This is a steampunk-themed guitar or bass pick.
I tweaked the width a little and used the gear's cogs on the face of the pick for extra support.
It turns out to be a pretty thick pick that shouldn't break unless someone is in a musical battle of souls with the Devil. Or something. http://www.knoxmakers.org Based off of carlosgs's Creepick. Uses John Carter's Pro Gear from the community models at Tinkercad.
